oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clinical cold stress in calves: Identification, environmental considerations, treatment and prevention.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Anderson, John F.
Bates, Donald W.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: calf diseases
calves
cold zones
Diagnosis
Disease prevention
Hypothermia
nutrition
Reviews
Young animal diseases
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Severe weather related stress in young dairy calves is often unrecognized. If the calf is born in a cold, wet environment and is not dried immediately following birth, susceptibility to hypothermia is markedly increased. A negative energy balance (hypothermia) develops as a result of the calf's thin haircoat, heat loss due to evaporation, the small amount of subcutaneous fat and incomplete development of body temperature control mechanisms. Physiological deterioration occurs rapidly under these conditions.
